name: src/consent.js
Consent
description: Consent information collected for a specific purpose

name: constructor
description: Create a new Consent

params.name: purpose
params.description: The purpose for which consent has been given

params.name: vendors
params.description: The vendors for which consent has been given (for that specific purpose)

name: addVendor
description: Add a new vendor to the consent, to indicate that the user has given consent for the pair (purpose, vendor)

name: src/token.js
CWT
description:
A consent web token represents the GDPR consents expressed by a user.
It can be used for storage or to be shared with third-parties.

name: constructor
description: Create a new Consent web token

params.name: tokenContent.issuer
params.description: A unique ID identifying the issuer of the token

params.name: tokenContent.user_id
params.description: The ID of the user that owns the token

params.name: tokenContent.user_id_type
params.description: The type of ID (email, uuid, adid, etc.)

params.name: tokenContent.user_id_hash_method
params.description: If the user ID is hashed, this is the method used for generating the hash (md5, sha1, sha256)

params.name: tokenContent.consents
params.description: A list of consents already given by the user

name: issuer
description: A unique ID identifying the issuer of the token

name: user_id
description: The ID of the user that owns the token

name: user_id_type
description: The type of ID (email, uuid, adid, etc.)

name: user_id_hash_method
description: If the user ID is hashed, this is the method used for generating the hash (md5, sha1, sha256)

name: consents
description: A list of consents already given by the user

name: version
description: The CWT specification version

name: toObject
description: Export the token information as a plain JavaScript object

name: toJSON
description: Generate a JSON-encoded version of the token

name: toBase64
description:
Generate a base64-encoded version of the token
It first encode the token as JSON then base64-encode it.

name: addConsent
description: Add a consent given by the user

params.name: purpose
params.description: The purpose for which the user has given consent

params.name: vendorId
params.description: The unique vendor ID for which the user has given consent. Use `*` to indicate that the user has given consent for all vendors)

params.name: scopeId
params.description: The scope for which the user has given consent (example: email, website, a unique internal ID, etc.). This is used to further limit the consent to a specific context as needed. It allows doing local (one website) vs global (all websites) consents easily. Use `*` to indicate that the user has given consent for any scope.

name: getConsent
description: Get the consent given by a user for a given purpose

return.description: The `Consent` object for the purpose or `null` if there is no consent for that purpose

name: hasConsent
description:
Check if the user has given consent for a specific purpose, vendor and scope

If the vendor or the scope are not provided, the function ignores them and simply checks if consent has been given for the purpose.
Make sure that you provide a vendor or scope to match the level of compliance you are targeting.
For instance, if you want to make sure that the user has given the most specific purpose, you'll want to include both the vendor and the scope in your query.

params.name: vendorId
params.description: Unique ID of the vendor to check consent for

name: CWTFromJSON
description: Parse a JSON string into a CWT object

return.description: Return a CWT object or null if the JSON does not represent a valid Consent Web Token

name: CWTFromBase64
description: Parse a base64-encoded JSON string into a CWT object

return.description: Return a CWT object or null if the string does not represent a valid Consent Web Token

name: Purposes
description:
List of standard GDPR purposes

This list is provided as part of the CWT specification but is not intended to be a complete/restrictive list. You are free to specify your own purposes. If you share tokens with third-parties though, they will need to know of to interpret your purpose IDs whereas you can expect them to know how to deal with the standard purposes provided here.

name: src/vendor.js
Vendor
description:
Vendor

A vendor for which consent can be collected

content:
{
  "name": "consentwebtoken",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "Consent web token implementation for node.js and the browser",
  "homepage": "https://www.consentwebtoken.io/",
  "repository": {
    "type": "git",
    "url": "git+https://github.com/didomi/cwt-node.git"
  },
  "keywords": [
    "consent",
    "token",
    "cwt",
    "gdpr"
  ],
  "license": "MIT",
  "bugs": {
    "url": "https://github.com/didomi/cwt-node/issues"
  },
  "files": [
    "dist/"
  ],
  "main": "dist/token.js",
  "directories": {
    "lib": "src",
    "test": "test"
  },
  "scripts": {
    "test": "mocha test/ --recursive",
    "coverage": "nyc --reporter=html --reporter=text-summary --reporter=lcov --check-coverage --lines 100 --functions 100 --branches 100 mocha test/ --recursive",
    "lint": "eslint src/. test/.",
    "docs": "esdoc",
    "build": "babel src --out-dir dist",
    "publish": "npm build && npm publish ."
  },
  "dependencies": {},
  "devDependencies": {
    "babel-cli": "^6.26.0",
    "babel-preset-env": "^1.6.1",
    "chai": "^4.0.2",
    "coveralls": "^3.0.0",
    "esdoc": "^1.0.4",
    "esdoc-standard-plugin": "^1.0.0",
    "eslint": "^4.0.0",
    "eslint-config-airbnb-base": "^11.2.0",
    "eslint-plugin-import": "^2.3.0",
    "eslint-plugin-mocha": "^4.11.0",
    "mocha": "^3.4.2",
    "nyc": "^11.0.2"
  }
}
name: package.json
